sentence: International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), better known as IBM, is set to report first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday.

And depending on who you ask (bulls versus bears), IBM is either misunderstood and needs more time for its business transformation to be completed, or the company is fighting a losing cloud battle to the likes of Salesforce.com (CRM) and Amazon (AMZN).

While there are signs of significant progress in terms of scaling back its legacy business towards higher margin/higher growth endeavors, revenue — despite ending the streak of 22 straight quarterly declines — remains an issue.
On Tuesday Wall Street will look to see if the Armonk, NY.-based tech bellwether, lead by CEO Ginni Rometty, can build on its revenue growth it achieved in Q4 or whether that was an aberration.
Particularly important will be the extent to which IBM can show that Strategic Imperatives can produce higher profit margins to offsets the revenue declines in the legacy business.
In other words, IBM has a lot to prove.
For the quarter that ended March, Wall Street expects the company to deliver earnings of $2.41 per share on revenue of $18.82 billion.
This compares the year-ago quarter when the company earned $2.35 per share on $18.16 billion in revenue.
For the full year, ending in December, earnings are projected to rise 1.31% year over year to $13.84 per share, while revenue of $80.26 billion would rise 1.4% year over year.

In the fourth quarter not only did the company report an impressive $5.18 per share which beat Wall Street estimates by 1 cent, revenue came to $22.54 billion, which for the first time in 23 quarters (almost six years) grew from the prior year (up 3.5%), topping forecasts by $500 million.
Growth in the company’s newer businesses, particularly Strategic Imperatives (includes IBM’s Watson AI), help offset declines in its legacy operations.
Strategic imperatives revenue, which during the year accounted for almost 50% of overall revenue, was up 14% in Q4, reaching $11.1 billion.
Meanwhile, not only did cloud revenue grow 27% year over year to $5.5 billion, it also achieved an annual run rate of $10.3 billion, up an impressive 18%.
Combined with a 21% jump in mobile revenue and 127% surge in security revenue, it’s tough to argue that IBM isn't heading in the right direction.
Investors will reward IBM stock to the extent that these growth trends can continue.
Perhaps even more important will be the guidance issued by management for the second quarter and full year, especially after last quarter’s return to revenue growth.
From a valuation perspective, these shares are cheap, trading at just 11 times fiscal 2018 estimates of $13.84 per share.
This tells me Wall Street is not pricing in breathtaking results.
So, purely from a risk-versus-reward perspective, IBM stock looks safe regardless of the reported numbers Tuesday, especially when factoring its 3.84% dividend yield.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
